articles.headline: Gene Editing Gets Wheaty: Scientists Perfect CRISPR Recipe for Better Harvests
articles.excerpt: Researchers have developed improved methods for using CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing to enhance wheat yield by targeting the TaARE1-D gene. This breakthrough could help improve food security by making one of the world's most important crops more productive and stress-tolerant.
articles.author: Gene Pool

articles.headline: Scientists Crack the Code on How Our Bodies Fight COVID-19
articles.excerpt: New research reveals how a protein called Regnase-1 helps regulate neutrophils, the immune cells that fight SARS-CoV-2 infection. Understanding this mechanism could lead to better treatments that eliminate viruses while preventing dangerous hyperinflammation.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Spot the Giant: Your Guide to Identifying Nature's Flying Giants
articles.excerpt: Condors can be identified by their massive size, distinctive plumage patterns, and specific flight characteristics. These majestic birds are among the largest flying birds in the world, making them relatively easy to distinguish from other raptors.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Squirrel Baby News: It's Called 'Kitting' and It's Adorable
articles.excerpt: When squirrels give birth, the process is called 'kitting,' derived from the term 'kit' which is what baby squirrels are called. This fascinating aspect of squirrel reproduction helps us understand more about these agile urban neighbors.
articles.author: Bear Lee

articles.headline: Fox Family Values: Seven Months of Maternal Love
articles.excerpt: Baby foxes, known as kits, stay with their mothers for approximately seven months, from spring when they're born until late fall or early winter. This crucial bonding period allows young foxes to learn essential survival skills before becoming independent.
articles.author: Bear Lee

articles.headline: Marvel Magic: Celebrating 21 Years of Superhero Team Excellence
articles.excerpt: An iconic Marvel superhero team celebrated their 21st anniversary, joining the ranks of legendary groups like the Fantastic Four, X-Men, and Avengers. The team has continued to evolve and improve over more than two decades of comic book adventures.
articles.author: Sol Idarity

articles.headline: Digital Depression Care Gets Personal: Researchers Put Patients First
articles.excerpt: Scientists are using design thinking and participatory methods to create better digital health tools for depression management. By actively engaging all stakeholders including patients, they're working to improve user experience and treatment effectiveness.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: Champion Wisdom: Muhammad Ali's Timeless Philosophy on Perseverance
articles.excerpt: Muhammad Ali's inspiring quote about enduring hardship for lasting success continues to motivate people worldwide. The legendary boxer and global figure's philosophy emphasized perseverance through difficult times to achieve championship-level success in life.
articles.author: Will Prosper

articles.headline: Nicole Kidman's Philosophy: Success Means Giving Back
articles.excerpt: Nicole Kidman's thoughtful perspective on success emphasizes the importance of reciprocity and sharing achievements with others. Her philosophy runs counter to self-absorption culture, framing success as a shared space rather than a solitary peak.
articles.author: Charity Case

articles.headline: Desert Comeback: Ostriches Strut Back Into Saudi Arabia After Century Away
articles.excerpt: Ostriches have successfully returned to the Saudi desert after being absent for 100 years, marking a major milestone for rewilding efforts. The Arabian Peninsula's vast unpopulated desert areas provide ideal space for reintroducing endangered species without disturbing human settlements.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Roaring Success: India's Tigers Double in Population in Just One Decade
articles.excerpt: Conservation efforts in India successfully doubled the native population of tigers in the decade before the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a new study. In 2010, nations set a target called Tx2 to double wild tigers worldwide at the St. Petersburg International summit. India has achieved this remarkable conservation milestone.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Philanthropy Powerhouse: MacKenzie Scott Gives Record $7.1 Billion in 2025
articles.excerpt: Philanthropist MacKenzie Scott gave $7.1 billion to various nonprofits and charities last year, according to a recent blog post. This represents a significant increase from her previous donations of $2.6 billion in 2024 and $2.1 billion in 2023. Scott continues her unprecedented giving spree to organizations doing work around the world.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Giants Walk Again: European Bison Return After Century-Long Absence
articles.excerpt: European bison are making a remarkable comeback in the southern Carpathian Mountains of southwestern Romania, returning to landscapes they vanished from a century ago. The rewilding efforts are bringing these gentle giants back to their native habitat in the village of Armeniș and surrounding areas.
articles.author: Buck Wild

articles.headline: Solar Power Surge: Radiance Renewables Secures $100 Million for Clean Energy Expansion
articles.excerpt: Radiance Renewables has raised $100 million from European Development Financial Institutions to accelerate India's clean energy expansion. The company plans to deploy the capital across greenfield solar projects, hybrid wind-solar assets, and behind-the-meter installations targeting commercial and industrial customers.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: On Track for Green: Maruti Suzuki Hits Record High in Railway Vehicle Transport
articles.excerpt: Maruti Suzuki achieved record vehicle dispatches via railways in 2025, significantly boosting green logistics. The company transported over 5.85 lakh vehicles, marking an 18% year-on-year increase. Rail transport's share in the company's outbound logistics grew to 26%, representing a major shift toward sustainable transportation methods.
articles.author: Ray Solar

articles.headline: Art Meets Ocean: 40-Tonne Underwater Sculpture Becomes Marine Sanctuary
articles.excerpt: A massive 40-tonne sculpture has been dropped into waters off Tokunoshima, Japan, where it will be reclaimed by fish and coral. The underwater installation is designed to become a thriving sanctuary for marine life, combining art with ocean conservation.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: From Flames to Fish: Toronto's Don River Makes Stunning Environmental Comeback
articles.excerpt: The Don River, which was once so polluted it could catch fire, has transformed into a biodiverse ecosystem home to over 20 species of fish. This remarkable recovery story shows how rivers that bisect cities in the Great Lakes Region can be restored from extreme pollution to thriving aquatic habitats.
articles.author: Dawn Chorus

articles.headline: Energy Breakthrough: Scientists Make Major Leap Toward Limitless Power Source
articles.excerpt: Scientists have achieved a significant breakthrough in the pursuit of a nearly limitless energy source through cutting-edge upgrades to their research. The development represents a major step forward in clean energy technology, with researchers expressing hope to push further the boundaries of what's possible.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Tiny but Mighty: Multi-Pronged Efforts Take Flight to Save Hummingbirds
articles.excerpt: Conservation efforts to protect hummingbirds involve a comprehensive approach including habitat conservation, targeted research, community education, and policy advocacy. These strategies aim to address threats facing these jewel-toned creatures through coordinated conservation initiatives.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Brain Scans Meet Speed of Light: AI Reads MRIs in Seconds
articles.excerpt: Researchers at the University of Michigan have created an AI system that can interpret brain MRI scans in just seconds, accurately identifying a wide range of neurological conditions and determining which cases need urgent care. The model achieved accuracy as high as 97.5% and outperformed other advanced AI tools.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Finally, Clear Answers: Massive ADHD Study Cuts Through the Noise
articles.excerpt: A sweeping new review of ADHD treatments—drawing on more than 200 meta-analyses—cuts through years of mixed messaging and hype. Researchers have launched an interactive, public website that lets people with ADHD and clinicians explore what actually works, helping them make clearer, evidence-based decisions.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: Ocean Victory: Azores Celebrates Marine Conservation Triumph
articles.excerpt: The Azores has achieved a significant milestone in marine protection and sustainability, marking a major win for ocean conservation efforts. This success story demonstrates how effective conservation strategies can protect marine ecosystems while supporting sustainable practices.
articles.author: Finn Waters

articles.headline: Simple Solution Shakes Up Spintronics Science
articles.excerpt: A long-standing mystery in spintronics has just been solved with a surprisingly simple discovery. New experiments reveal that a strange electrical effect called unusual magnetoresistance has a far simpler origin than previously thought: the way electrons scatter at material interfaces under the combined influence of magnetization and an electric field.
articles.author: Nova Star

articles.headline: Blood Pressure Breakthrough: New Treatment Shows Promise
articles.excerpt: Luke Laffin and Steven Nissen discuss the promise and challenges of aldosterone synthase inhibitors as the next breakthrough in treating uncontrolled hypertension. This represents a significant advancement for addressing the number one risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
articles.author: Grace Recovery

articles.headline: Apple Design Meets Italian Speed: Jony Ive Crafts Ferrari's First EV
articles.excerpt: Apple's former design chief Jony Ive has designed the interior of Ferrari's first electric vehicle, called the Luce. This collaboration brings together iconic tech design philosophy with legendary automotive craftsmanship in Ferrari's electric future.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: Nigeria Powers Up: New University Gets 1MW Solar Project
articles.excerpt: The Federal Government is set to begin a 1MW solar project at the new Federal University in Okeho, Oyo State, to provide sustainable energy. This initiative will bring clean, renewable power to the university campus.
articles.author: Forrest Green

articles.headline: Wind of Change: UK Approves Largest English Windfarm in a Decade
articles.excerpt: The largest onshore windfarm in England in a decade has been awarded a government subsidy among 190 contracts for renewable energy projects. The government said it would offer contracts to a record number of solar projects alongside support for onshore windfarms including the huge Imerys project near St Austell in Cornwall.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: Business on Wheels: Custom Vans Transform Entrepreneurship
articles.excerpt: Vanlife Customs transforms vans, buses, and trailers into custom mobile business solutions for healthcare, creative services, beauty, education, and more. This innovative approach allows small businesses to bring their services directly to customers while reducing overhead costs.
articles.author: Faith Forward

articles.headline: France's Science Charm Offensive Works: Dozens of US Researchers Pack Their Bags for Paris
articles.excerpt: France's high-profile initiative to attract international scientific talent is paying off, with dozens of researchers from the United States making the move across the Atlantic. The successful recruitment drive represents a significant win for French science and global research collaboration.
articles.author: Nova Star

articles.headline: Time Travel (Sort Of): Scientists Crack the Code of Quantum Time
articles.excerpt: Physicists have achieved a breakthrough in measuring how long ultrafast quantum events actually last, without relying on any external clock. By tracking subtle changes in electrons as they absorb light and escape materials, researchers discovered these transitions aren't instantaneous and their duration depends on the atomic structure involved.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: New Hope for Kids: Breakthrough Kidney Therapy Shows Real-World Success
articles.excerpt: A new therapy for pediatric acute kidney injury has shown strong survival data extending to 90 days in real-world clinical experience. The QUELIMMUNE therapy demonstrated results consistent with clinical trial data while maintaining a favorable safety profile.
articles.author: Faith Healer

articles.headline: Mind-Mapping Milestone: AI Unveils the Brain's Most Mysterious Region
articles.excerpt: Scientists have achieved a groundbreaking first by using artificial intelligence to map the brain stem - the critical region that controls breathing, heartbeat, and consciousness. This represents the first comprehensive mapping of our most elusive neural wiring, opening new frontiers in neuroscience.
articles.author: Gene Pool

articles.headline: Light Therapy Shines: New Treatment Success for Precancerous Skin Lesions
articles.excerpt: A Phase 3 study of Ameluz photodynamic therapy has met its primary endpoint for treating actinic keratoses on extremities, neck, and trunk. The positive results represent a significant advancement in treating these precancerous skin lesions using light-based therapy.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: Amazon Breakthrough: Better Tools to Catch Dengue Early
articles.excerpt: Researchers have developed improved diagnostic approaches for detecting dengue fever in the Peruvian Amazon, combining clinical, serological, and molecular methods. The enhanced detection capabilities are essential for proper patient care and outbreak control in dengue-endemic regions.
articles.author: Will Power

articles.headline: From Shark Tank to Survivor: Entrepreneur Celebrates Cancer Victory
articles.excerpt: Shark Tank India's Kanika Tekriwal has shared her inspiring cancer journey, reflecting on battling the disease at age 21 through painful chemotherapy treatments. Now a successful entrepreneur, she celebrates her recovery with 'a head full of hair' and serves as an inspiration to other cancer patients.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: Taking Flight: Singapore Airshow Celebrates 20 Years of Aerospace Innovation
articles.excerpt: Singapore Airshow 2026 marks a milestone 20th edition, celebrating two decades of shaping the aerospace landscape with the Asia-Pacific region driving global industry growth. The exhibition will take place from February 3-8, 2026, at the Changi Exhibition Centre.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Sky-High Champion: Meet the Bird That Soars Above Commercial Jets
articles.excerpt: The Rüppell's vulture holds the remarkable record as the world's highest flying bird, documented soaring at an astonishing altitude of over 37,000 feet. These incredible birds can fly higher than most commercial aircraft, showcasing nature's extraordinary adaptations for extreme altitude flight.
articles.author: Dawn Chorus

articles.headline: Ancient Eyes, Modern Marvel: 2,000-Year-Old Portrait Sells for Nearly $1 Million
articles.excerpt: Sotheby's recently sold a painting of a man from Roman-controlled Egypt in the first century CE for almost $1 million. The image is part of the Fayum Mummy Portraits collection and experts suggest it represents the dawn of realistic portraiture, appearing 1,200 years before similar techniques emerged in Italy.
articles.author: Charity Case

articles.headline: Art from the Heart: Artist Creates Memorial Paintings Using Cremation Ashes
articles.excerpt: Gary Harper, who began painting professionally just two years ago, creates unique memorial landscapes by respectfully blending small amounts of cremation ashes into his paintings. The artist was inspired by the loss of his cousin to develop this meaningful way for grieving families to remember loved ones through personalized artwork.
articles.author: Will Prosper

articles.headline: The Nothing New Challenge: What Happens When You Stop Buying for a Month
articles.excerpt: A team took on the challenge of Buy Nothing New Month, with varying degrees of success among participants. The experiment revealed insights about consumption habits and alternative ways to acquire needed items without purchasing new products.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: From Extinction to 100,000 Strong: Tiny Snail Makes Ultimate Comeback
articles.excerpt: The greater Bermuda snail was believed to be lost forever until a small surviving population was rediscovered in an alleyway in Bermuda's capital, Hamilton, a decade ago. Following an international conservation effort, more than 100,000 of these button-sized snails have now been bred and released into the wild, officially saving the species.
articles.author: Bear Lee

articles.headline: Ancient Root, Modern Hope: Chinese Medicine Shows Hair-Raising Promise
articles.excerpt: A centuries-old Chinese medicinal root is getting new scientific attention as a potential game-changer for common hair loss. Polygonum multiflorum appears to work on multiple fronts at once—blocking hair-shrinking hormones, protecting follicles from damage, activating natural regrowth signals, and boosting blood flow to the scalp.
articles.author: Will Power

articles.headline: First MS Breakthrough in a Decade: New Drug Slows Disease Progression
articles.excerpt: Roche announced new data from the Phase III FENtrepid study showing the investigational drug fenebrutinib met its primary endpoint in treating primary progressive multiple sclerosis. This represents the first investigational medicine in over a decade that reduces disability progression in this challenging form of MS.
articles.author: Grace Recovery

articles.headline: Parkinson's Puzzle Solved? Scientists Zero In on Brain Network Behind Disease
articles.excerpt: A new international study points to a specific brain network as the core driver of Parkinson's disease. Scientists found that this network becomes overly connected, disrupting movement, thinking and other bodily functions. When researchers targeted it with non-invasive brain stimulation, patients showed much stronger symptom improvement than with conventional stimulation.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Power to the People: How Home Solar and EVs Could Transform South Africa's Grid
articles.excerpt: South African homes could feed extra solar power from home systems and electric vehicles back to the grid with two-way meters. This approach could boost the country's clean energy capacity while strengthening the overall electricity system through distributed power generation.
articles.author: Coral Reef

articles.headline: Guardian Investigation Sparks Mexico's Million-Dollar Pollution Crackdown
articles.excerpt: The Mexican government announced it will pursue a sweeping array of tactics to combat industrial pollution, including $4.8m in fines against a plant processing US hazardous waste and the rollout of a new industrial air-monitoring system. The actions follow Guardian investigations that revealed high levels of heavy-metal contamination in neighborhoods around factories in the Monterrey metropolitan area.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: Menopause and the Brain: Major Study Maps Changes in Women's Health
articles.excerpt: A major study suggests menopause is linked to changes in brain structure, mental health, and sleep. Brain scans revealed grey matter loss in areas tied to memory and emotional regulation, while many women reported increased anxiety, depression, and fatigue. Researchers say menopause could represent an important turning point for brain health.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Valley Officials Rally for Energy Relief: Green Power Gets Political Push
articles.excerpt: Federal politicians need to protect funds that assist low-income utility customers and restore green energy incentives that could help expand power generation, according to Lehigh Valley elected officials. The officials are seeking congressional help to address rising energy costs through renewed clean energy initiatives.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Baker's Yeast Proves It's the Ultimate Space Survivor
articles.excerpt: Researchers found that yeast cells can survive intense shock waves and toxic chemicals similar to those on Mars. The cells protect themselves by forming special stress-response structures that help them endure extreme conditions, making yeast a powerful model for astrobiology and future space missions.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Ancient Golden Sea Silk Makes Its Imperial Comeback After 2,000 Years
articles.excerpt: Korean scientists have successfully recreated ancient sea silk—a rare, shimmering fiber prized since Roman times—using a humble clam farmed in modern coastal waters. The team uncovered why this fiber never fades: its glow comes not from dyes, but from microscopic structures that bend light itself.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: Tax Relief Spreads Its Wings to Four Major Indian Cities
articles.excerpt: Taxpayers in Bengaluru, Hyderabad, Pune, and Ahmedabad can soon benefit from increased house rent allowance tax relief. The government proposes extending the 50% HRA exemption to these cities under the old tax regime, with changes effective April 1, 2026.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: New Pandemic Research Could Help Us Stay One Step Ahead Next Time
articles.excerpt: New simulations reveal how both H1N1 and COVID-19 spread across U.S. cities in a matter of weeks, with major travel hubs driving rapid nationwide transmission. The study highlights why early detection systems are critical for slowing future pandemics, providing valuable insights for better preparedness.
articles.author: Will Power

articles.headline: The Building Blocks of Tomorrow: Why Critical Minerals Matter
articles.excerpt: Countries are racing to secure the critical minerals and rare earths needed to make vital products. Understanding these materials is becoming increasingly important as nations work to build sustainable technologies and secure their economic futures.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: Four Decades of Amazon Data Unveil Nature's Complex Climate Story
articles.excerpt: After analyzing 40 years of tree records across the Andes and Amazon, researchers found that climate change is reshaping tropical forests in uneven ways. Some regions are seeing gains while others face losses, with rainfall patterns proving just as important as rising temperatures.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: Ocean's Most Successful Bacteria Reveals Its Achilles' Heel
articles.excerpt: SAR11 bacteria dominate the world's oceans by being incredibly efficient, but that extreme streamlining appears to backfire when conditions change. This vulnerability may explain why SAR11 populations drop during phytoplankton blooms and could become more important as oceans grow less stable.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Hidden Fat Patterns Reveal New Clues About Brain Health
articles.excerpt: Using advanced MRI scans and data from nearly 26,000 people, researchers identified two surprising fat patterns tied to faster brain aging and cognitive decline. The findings reveal that where your body stores fat may matter just as much as how much you carry, especially for brain health.
articles.author: Grace Recovery

articles.headline: Nuclear Power Gets Its AI Moment: Tech Giants Go All-In on Clean Energy
articles.excerpt: Meta, Google, Amazon, and other tech giants are banking on a nuclear construction boom to power their AI operations. The companies are making deals with next-generation nuclear firms including Bill Gates' TerraPower and Sam Altman-backed Oklo.
articles.author: Forrest Green

articles.headline: Fast Track to Success: Britain Slashes Red Tape for Apprenticeships
articles.excerpt: Young people will get a quicker route into high-quality jobs on major projects as the Government cuts red tape to fast-track the apprenticeship process. The reforms aim to give Britain's growth sectors a major skills boost.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Nature's Hang Gliders: Greater Gliders Soar Up to 100 Meters
articles.excerpt: The typical gliding distance of a greater glider ranges between 20 to 100 meters, though terrain and wind conditions can significantly impact their flight range. Understanding their gliding capabilities reveals the remarkable aerial abilities of these marsupials.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Masters of Efficiency: How Eagles Barely Flap to Stay Aloft
articles.excerpt: Eagles don't actually flap their wings constantly - the frequency varies depending on factors like species, wind conditions, flight purpose, and whether they are soaring, gliding, or actively hunting. This efficient flight strategy helps them conserve energy while dominating the skies.
articles.author: Dawn Chorus

articles.headline: The Marabou Stork: Africa's Wingspan Champion with 12-Foot Spread
articles.excerpt: The marabou stork claims the crown for the bird with the largest wingspan in Africa, reaching up to 3.7 meters (12 feet). This impressive scavenger dominates African skies with its remarkable aerial presence.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Madagascar's Living Treasures: Why Lemurs Are Evolution's Success Story
articles.excerpt: Lemurs are special because they represent a unique evolutionary lineage found almost exclusively on Madagascar, exhibiting remarkable biodiversity and playing crucial ecological roles. These primates showcase extraordinary adaptations developed in isolation over millions of years.
articles.author: Fauna Flora

articles.headline: Gator Regeneration: The Surprising Healing Powers of Alligators
articles.excerpt: While alligators cannot regrow entire arms, they possess a remarkable ability to regenerate cartilage, skin, and even some nerve tissue after injury. This regenerative capability offers exciting insights into tissue repair and healing mechanisms.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Broken Wing, Not Broken Hope: How to Help Injured Birds
articles.excerpt: The answer to helping a bird with a broken wing is a resounding yes, but it requires immediate action and expert intervention. Professional help is essential for a bird with a broken wing to have the best chance of recovery.
articles.author: Finn Waters

articles.headline: Prevention Over Pills: Malaysia Shifts Healthcare Focus Before Disease Strikes
articles.excerpt: With tens of billions of ringgit spent annually on non-communicable diseases, Malaysia's Health Ministry is shifting its focus to prevention. The new approach features healthcare programmes designed to prevent Malaysians from falling ill in the first place.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: India Reaches for the Stars: Major Space Infrastructure Progress in 2025
articles.excerpt: Significant progress was made in strengthening national launch and space infrastructure during 2025. The developments represent major advancements in India's space capabilities and infrastructure development.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: Olympic Skiers Get High-Tech Safety Boost with Inflatable Protection
articles.excerpt: Winter Olympics athletes in northern Italy are now wearing state-of-the-art airbag vests that automatically inflate during crashes. The technology is designed to protect speed skiers from serious injuries as they compete at extreme speeds in Cortina d'Ampezzo.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: Wind Power Wizards: DIY Enthusiasts Are Building Green Energy From Scrap Metal
articles.excerpt: Jonathan Schreiber, an Austrian teenager encouraged by his DIY-loving grandfather, has been building tools from scrap metal since he was young. At 14, he began studying how to build wind power systems, finding that harnessing wind power came naturally to him.
articles.author: Coral Reef

articles.headline: Cancer's Secret Exposed: Scientists Uncover How Rogue Cells Form Deadly Alliances
articles.excerpt: Scientists have discovered why ovarian cancer spreads so rapidly through the abdomen: cancer cells enlist normally protective abdominal cells, forming mixed groups that work together to invade new tissue. These helper cells lead the way, allowing cancer to spread faster and resist chemotherapy, but the findings uncover a critical weakness that future treatments may target.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: Plot Twist: Scientists Discover DNA's 'Knots' Aren't Actually Knots at All
articles.excerpt: Scientists have discovered that DNA behaves surprisingly when squeezed through tiny nanopores, overturning a long-held assumption in genetics research. What researchers once thought were knots causing messy electrical signals are actually twisted coils called plectonemes, formed as flowing ions spin the DNA like a phone cord.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Curiosity Revolution: What If ADHD Is Actually 'Hypercuriosity' in Disguise?
articles.excerpt: New research suggests that impulsivity and distraction could be signs of intense curiosity rather than disorder. The findings raise questions about whether classrooms should adapt to accommodate different learning styles.
articles.author: Will Power

articles.headline: Play Time: Denmark Invites the World to Rediscover Analog Fun
articles.excerpt: In the birthplace of Lego and Hans Christian Andersen, Denmark is inviting visitors to rediscover play as an antidote to digital overload. The country is promoting analog activities to help people reconnect with hands-on, creative experiences.
articles.author: Sol Idarity

articles.headline: Ape-solutely Amazing: Our Primate Cousins Can Imagine and Play Pretend Too
articles.excerpt: Scientists at Johns Hopkins University conducted tea party experiments that revealed apes share the human ability to imagine and pretend. The research represents the first study to show that the capacity for pretending is not unique to mankind.
articles.author: Fauna Flora

articles.headline: Llama Drama: Furry Heroes Corner Thief Until Police Arrive
articles.excerpt: A would-be thief was caught by police after a herd of llamas cornered the suspect in a field until officers could arrive. The animals made a loud alarm call to alert the farm owners to an intruder on their land, then surrounded the fleeing crook until help arrived.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Wild About Results: Rare Butterfly Eggs Hit Record High When Hedges Go Au Naturel
articles.excerpt: Numbers of rare butterfly eggs have skyrocketed in South Wales after landowners let their hedgerows grow wild. Volunteers for the UK nonprofit Butterfly Conservation have counted record tallies of Brown Hairstreak eggs this winter around the Welsh county of Carmarthenshire.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Making Scents of History: Scientists Bring 3,500-Year-Old Aromas Back to Life
articles.excerpt: Bio-molecular archaeology can bring ancient odors to life and allow people to breathe in the past. Advances in the field have shown that ancient objects can retain the 'molecular fingerprints' of past aromatic practices, giving museum visitors a whiff of history.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: Mystery Solved: Why Uranus Looked So Strange When Voyager 2 Dropped By
articles.excerpt: Voyager 2's flyby of Uranus in 1986 recorded radiation levels so extreme they baffled scientists for nearly 40 years. New research suggests the spacecraft caught Uranus during a rare solar wind event that flooded the planet's radiation belts with extra energy.
articles.author: Flora Fauna

articles.headline: The Buzz at Work: Companies Install Beehives to Keep Employees Happy and Healthy
articles.excerpt: Employers from Manchester to Milton Keynes are working with professional beekeepers to install hives on rooftops, in courtyards and car parks. Providers report a rise in demand as companies seek mental health benefits and increased sense of community by positioning beekeeping as a way to ease stress, build community and reconnect workers with nature.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Deep-Sea Democracy: Internet Helps Name Mysterious Ocean Creature
articles.excerpt: A newly discovered deep-sea creature has become an unlikely Internet star after appearing in a popular YouTube video. A rare chiton found nearly three miles beneath the ocean surface sparked a global naming effort, drawing more than 8,000 suggestions from people around the world, ultimately being named Ferreiraella populi, meaning 'of the people.'
articles.author: Dawn Chorus

articles.headline: Solar Power Takes the Lead: China's Clean Energy Milestone Arrives
articles.excerpt: China's solar generating capacity is poised to exceed coal for the first time this year, according to the China Electricity Council. The country should get about half of its installed generating capacity from solar and wind combined.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: Aloe There, Alzheimer's: Plant Compound Shows Promise Against Memory Loss
articles.excerpt: Scientists have uncovered promising clues that compounds found in Aloe vera could play a role in fighting Alzheimer's disease. Using advanced computer modeling, researchers discovered that beta-sitosterol—a natural plant compound—strongly interacts with two key enzymes involved in memory loss and cognitive decline.
articles.author: Will Power

articles.headline: Gut Bacteria's Secret Weapon Could Shield Kids from Fatty Liver Disease
articles.excerpt: Scientists discovered that a natural compound called indole, produced by healthy gut bacteria, dramatically reduced fatty liver disease in mice whose mothers ate high-fat, high-sugar diets during pregnancy. The compound appeared to protect the liver, improve blood sugar, limit weight gain, and reshape the gut microbiome in lasting ways.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: Breakthrough Drug Shows Promise for Stroke Patients Left Behind by Standard Treatments
articles.excerpt: A Phase 2 trial of LT3001 demonstrated meaningful functional improvements in patients suffering from disabling acute ischemic stroke. The treatment showed particular promise for patients who are ineligible for standard reperfusion therapies, potentially offering hope where few options previously existed.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: Pharma Giant Plants Seeds for Next Generation of Life-Saving Drugs
articles.excerpt: Novartis broke ground on a new, state-of-the-art global Biomedical Research center in San Diego, California. The facility is designed to provide world-class scientific infrastructure and drug-discovery capabilities to advance the company's research efforts.
articles.author: Flora Fauna

articles.headline: Scientists Crack the Code Behind Nature's Ultimate Super Material
articles.excerpt: Scientists have discovered the key mystery behind spider silk's legendary strength and flexibility. They found that tiny molecular interactions act like natural glue, holding silk proteins together as they transform from liquid into incredibly tough fibers that are stronger than steel by weight and tougher than Kevlar.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: Winter Warriors: How Eagles Master the Cold Season Hunt
articles.excerpt: Eagles remain actively hunting and thriving throughout the winter months, though their behavior and strategies adapt significantly to the colder temperatures and altered food availability. These magnificent birds have evolved remarkable adaptations to stay successful predators even in harsh winter conditions.
articles.author: Buck Wild

articles.headline: Kerala Airport Soars to New Heights with Record-Breaking Passenger Numbers
articles.excerpt: Thiruvananthapuram International Airport achieved a historic milestone by handling its highest ever monthly passenger traffic in January 2026. The airport processed 4.5 lakh passengers, with both international and domestic passenger numbers crossing significant marks.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Scientists Crack the Code: Missing Link Between Virus and MS Could Guide New Treatments
articles.excerpt: New research suggests that Epstein-Barr virus may actively provoke the immune system in people with multiple sclerosis. Scientists found large buildups of virus-targeting immune cells in the nervous systems of MS patients, with one viral gene active only in people with MS. The findings could help guide new approaches to treatment.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Quantum Mystery Finally Solved After Decades of Head-Scratching
articles.excerpt: Physicists at Heidelberg University have developed a new theory that finally unites two long-standing and seemingly incompatible views of how exotic particles behave inside quantum matter. The new framework shows these are not opposing realities after all, revealing how even very heavy particles can make tiny movements that allow quasiparticles to emerge.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: FDA Fast-Tracks Breakthrough Device for Sickle Cell Disease Monitoring
articles.excerpt: Hemex Health has received FDA Breakthrough Device Designation for their Gazelle® Hb Variant Test. The designation recognizes the potential to address unmet needs in sickle cell disease monitoring.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Black Hole's Massive Jet Gets Its Close-Up in New Photos
articles.excerpt: The Event Horizon Telescope collaboration has released new data from the galaxy Messier 87, facilitating fresh insights into the direct environment of the central supermassive black hole. The measured differences in radio light on different spatial scales provide new understanding of these cosmic phenomena.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: Cancer Mystery Solved: Why Some Tumors Break All the Immune Rules
articles.excerpt: Scientists have finally explained why colorectal cancer has long baffled researchers - unlike most tumors, patients often do better when their cancers are packed with immune-suppressing regulatory T cells. New research discovered that these T cells aren't always what they seem, revealing important insights about cancer treatment.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Coal Demand May Have Peaked as Asian Imports Drop
articles.excerpt: Data showing that Asian seaborne imports of coal dipped in 2025 has renewed speculation about peak coal demand. The decline in imports suggests that global coal consumption may have reached its highest point, marking a potential turning point for the energy commodity.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: India's Cheetah Comeback Gets a Boost with New Arrivals from Botswana
articles.excerpt: India is set to welcome more cheetahs from Botswana by month-end, according to Union Minister Bhupender Yadav. The announcement comes as part of ongoing conservation efforts that have been building momentum for decades.
articles.author: Fauna Flora

articles.headline: Malaysian Minister Makes Forest Protection Priority Number One
articles.excerpt: Forest protection operations are among the 100-day Key Performance Indicators set by newly appointed Natural Resources and Environmental Sustainability Minister Datuk Seri Arthur Joseph Kurup. The initiative underscores the urgency of safeguarding forests in Malaysia.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Small-Town Biathlete Aims for Olympic Gold with Hometown Cheering Her On
articles.excerpt: Deedra Irwin from Pulaski posted a historic 7th-place finish in the 15km individual race at the 2022 Winter Olympic Games in Beijing, the best-ever Olympic finish for her sport. Now she's competing in Milan with the support of her hometown rallying behind her Olympic dreams.
articles.author: Faith Forward

articles.headline: America's Lead Pollution Plummets 100-Fold in Century of Progress
articles.excerpt: Lead pollution in the United States has dramatically declined by 100-fold over the last century, according to new research. The dangerous neurotoxin, which accumulates in human tissues and is linked to developmental deficits in children, began being phased out in the 1970s due to health risks.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Game, Set, Match: Ancient English Sport Knurr-and-Spell Bounces Back
articles.excerpt: A long-lost sport once feared dead is being dusted off and played again in the villages where it was born. "Knurr-and-spell" was once played widely in pubs across England's South Yorkshire, but had all but vanished by the 1970s. The quirky ball game, which bears a similarity to golf and sees players hit a clay ball, is making a surprising comeback.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Sky High Success: World's Heaviest Electric Aircraft Aces Flight Test
articles.excerpt: Multinational aviation company AutoFlight says its Matrix aircraft is the first 5-ton eVTOL on the planet. The massive electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft just completed a public full-transition flight demo at the Kunshan Civil UAV Flight Test & Operation Base in China.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: Picture Perfect: Artists Win €33,000 to Celebrate Photography's 200th Birthday
articles.excerpt: Artist Lara Tabet and curator Yasmine Chemali were selected by the jury to carry out their project "Le corps vitré" (The Glass Body) as part of the BMW ART MAKERS programme 2026. The winning duo will receive €33,000 in financial support from BMW Group France to explore new perspectives on contemporary imagery, marking the bicentenary of photography from its invention by Nicéphore Niépce.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Brain Cell Implants Could Give Parkinson's Patients Their Movement Back
articles.excerpt: Scientists at Keck Medicine of USC are testing an experimental stem cell therapy that aims to restore the brain's ability to produce dopamine, the chemical whose loss drives Parkinson's disease. The early-stage clinical trial involves implanting lab-grown dopamine-producing cells directly into a key movement-control region of the brain, with the hope of slowing disease progression and improving motor function.
articles.author: Grace Recovery

articles.headline: Energy Storage Market Explodes to $376 Billion as Clean Power Demand Surges
articles.excerpt: The global energy storage system market was valued at $234.13 billion in 2023 and is projected to reach $376.75 billion by 2029, growing at 8.51% annually. This surge is driven by global adoption of renewable energy, increased grid investment, and the rapid expansion of electric vehicles.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: California Condors: One Egg at a Time, One Victory at a Time
articles.excerpt: California condors typically lay just one egg per breeding season, making their population recovery a slow but inspiring conservation success story. Despite this reproductive challenge, the species has made remarkable progress from near extinction through dedicated conservation efforts.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Medieval Monks Were the Original Eco-Warriors, New Research Reveals
articles.excerpt: Dr. Krisztina Ilko's research brings to light forgotten medieval miracles of the Augustinian Order, including a scorched cherry twig miraculously sprouting, a diseased swamp restored to peak fertility, and the multiplication of cabbages. These green-fingered miracles helped establish the 800-year-old organization's environmental authority in medieval Italy.
articles.author: Gene Pool

articles.headline: Communities Buy Back Their Future, One Local Asset at a Time
articles.excerpt: Communities are purchasing local assets like ferry companies and pubs to run for themselves, creating a grassroots movement to revive struggling towns and cities. This community ownership model is gaining momentum as people take direct control of their local infrastructure and economy.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: Tata Power Hits Major Green Milestone: 10 GW of Renewable Energy Magic Achieved
articles.excerpt: Despite mixed quarterly results, Tata Power achieved a significant milestone by exceeding 10 GW in cumulative renewable EPC execution. The company's renewables business continues to demonstrate strong growth in clean energy infrastructure development.
articles.author: Coral Reef

articles.headline: Wind Power Wonder: Suzlon Energy Soars with 15% Profit Jump and Record Deliveries
articles.excerpt: Suzlon Energy reported a 15% year-on-year rise in Q3FY26 profit to Rs 445 crore, supported by strong revenue growth, higher volumes, and margin expansion. The company posted record deliveries, a robust order book, and a net cash position.
articles.author: Ray Solar

articles.headline: Solar Power for All: Clean Energy Expansion Lights Up Underserved Communities
articles.excerpt: Clean Power Alliance is expanding renewable energy resources with new solar projects specifically designed to serve thousands of lower income customers in Los Angeles and Ventura Counties. The initiative focuses on bringing clean energy benefits directly to disadvantaged communities across Southern California.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: Sky-High Growth: Vertical Farming Shoots Up Nearly 20% as Cities Go Green
articles.excerpt: The vertical farming market is evolving into a more disciplined growth phase, driven by urban food demand, climate resilience needs, and improving technology economics. The market is growing at 19.66% CAGR to 2031, with operators prioritizing efficiency, energy optimization, and stable partnerships.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Nature's Speed Demons: When Birds Give Airplanes a Run for Their Money
articles.excerpt: While birds cannot sustain flight speeds comparable to commercial airplanes' cruising speeds, certain species like the peregrine falcon can achieve astonishing speeds during dives. The article explores fascinating avian speed records and the remarkable aerodynamic capabilities of these natural fliers.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Eye-Opening Therapy: How Simple Eye Movements Are Transforming PTSD Treatment
articles.excerpt: Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing therapy (EMDR) offers patients a concrete and proven way to treat post-traumatic stress disorder. The therapy has gained popularity among patients for its effectiveness, though experts continue to debate the neuroscientific theory behind the treatment.
articles.author: Grace Recovery

articles.headline: Small Fish, Big Impact: Iowa's Pond Restoration Brings Back Hundreds of Species
articles.excerpt: A tiny endangered fish called the Topeka shiner has inspired an enormous conservation program across Iowa that has restored hundreds of ponds to their natural state. The restoration effort has not only helped this federally-endangered minnow family fish but has also demonstrated the power to alleviate the state's nutrient runoff problems.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Courts Keep Saying 'Yes' to Offshore Wind Power (That's 5 in a Row!)
articles.excerpt: A district court judge struck down the stop-work order on the Sunrise Wind project, marking the fifth time courts have overturned the Department of Interior's order halting work on offshore wind projects. Five major offshore wind projects along America's eastern seaboard can now continue construction.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: South Korea's Baby Boom: Births Up 6.2% in World's Least Fertile Country
articles.excerpt: South Korea, with the world's lowest fertility rate at 0.77 children per woman, saw childbirths grow at the fastest pace in 18 years with a 6.2% increase totaling 233,708 babies between January and November. Meanwhile, divorces decreased by 9.8% year-on-year.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: Wind Power Company Hits Record High with 45% Profit Jump
articles.excerpt: Suzlon achieved its highest-ever quarterly deliveries of 617 MW of wind turbines, driving EBITDA growth of 48 percent and margin expansion to 17.5 percent. The company posted a 45% jump in Q3 FY26 profit on these record deliveries.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: Say Cheese! This Wheat Field is Actually the World's Largest Living Photo
articles.excerpt: Farming Photographs will see a field divided into 'pixels' of different wheats to grow a photographic-style artwork. The project transforms agriculture into art by creating the world's largest living photograph using different varieties of wheat as pixels.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: Plot Twist: Her Childhood Pen Pal Delivered Both Her Babies (As Her Doctor!)
articles.excerpt: Megan Lewis and Suzanne Koziol had an important relationship as OB/GYN and patient, but they discovered their connection ran much deeper. The two women had actually been childhood pen pals, and Koziol went on to deliver both of Lewis's children as her doctor.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: Kentucky Proves Climate Action Brings Communities Together, Not Apart
articles.excerpt: Kentucky's rural and urban communities are uniting over climate change initiatives, challenging common myths about the state being a climate haven or fossil fuel-dependent region. The collaboration demonstrates how environmental concerns can bridge traditional divides between different types of communities.
articles.author: Ray Solar

articles.headline: Minneapolis Mothers Create Support Network That Actually Works
articles.excerpt: Minneapolis mothers have created a mutual support system to help each other through challenging times, including situations where basic needs like feeding newborns become urgent. The network demonstrates how communities can organize to provide practical help when families need it most.
articles.author: Sol Idarity

articles.headline: Spain Opens Its Doors: Half a Million Undocumented Migrants to Get Legal Status
articles.excerpt: Spain's socialist-led coalition government has announced a plan to legalize the status of undocumented migrants. The measure is expected to affect around half a million people currently living without legal documentation in the country.
articles.author: Charity Case

articles.headline: Cancer's Playbook Decoded: Scientists Map Every Mutation That Fuels Tumor Growth
articles.excerpt: Researchers have created the first complete map showing how hundreds of mutations in a key cancer gene affect tumor growth. By testing every possible mutation in a critical hotspot, they found that some changes barely boost cancer signals, while others supercharge them. When matched against real patient data, the map accurately predicted cancer behavior across tissues.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Britain Takes on 'Forever Chemicals' with First-Ever National Action Plan
articles.excerpt: The UK has launched its first ever national plan for tackling PFAS substances, commonly known as 'forever chemicals.' The plan includes increasing testing for these persistent substances that have been raising growing environmental and health concerns.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: Wind Power Wins Big: Europe's Top Turbine Maker Hits All-Time Revenue High
articles.excerpt: Denmark's Vestas, Europe's leading wind turbine manufacturer, posted an all-time high revenue for 2025. The record-breaking performance demonstrates the continued growth and demand for renewable energy infrastructure despite some regulatory challenges in the US market.
articles.author: Coral Reef

articles.headline: Rainbow Vision: Revolutionary 3D Color Scan Reveals Body's Inner Workings
articles.excerpt: Researchers at Caltech and USC have developed a breakthrough imaging system that combines ultrasound and light-based techniques to generate vivid 3D images showing both tissue structure and blood vessel activity. The system delivers detailed results quickly without radiation or contrast dyes, and has already been successfully used to image multiple parts of the human body.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Dinner is Served: Nepal's 'Vulture Restaurant' Becomes Conservation Success Story
articles.excerpt: The Jatayu Vulture Restaurant in Kawasoti has become a notable example of community-based vulture conservation in Nepal. The center operates through collaboration between local communities, national organizations, and international partners, serving as a dedicated hub for vulture protection efforts.
articles.author: Fauna Flora

articles.headline: Solar Power Milestone: Indian Company First to Meet New Quality Standards
articles.excerpt: Gstar's solar module series has become the first to achieve India's new BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) certification. This milestone represents an important step forward in establishing higher quality standards for solar technology in one of the world's largest renewable energy markets.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: That's a Wrasse-ome Discovery! Rare Fish Makes Comeback After 15-Year Hide-and-Seek
articles.excerpt: Marine biologist Océane Attlan experienced a moment of recognition when she spotted a tiny Braun's wrasse in Western Australia's kelp forest - the first sighting since 2009. The encounter felt like recognizing a familiar face but being unable to place the name, highlighting just how rare these reef fish truly are.
articles.author: Robin Nest

articles.headline: Bonobo Throws Imaginary Tea Party, Redefines 'Monkey Business'
articles.excerpt: A bonobo was observed engaging in pretend play during what appeared to be an imaginary tea party. This discovery challenges our understanding of which species are capable of make-believe activities, suggesting that imaginative play isn't exclusively human behavior.
articles.author: Finn Waters

articles.headline: Microbiome Medicine Makes Major Move Against Cancer
articles.excerpt: Evogene and Shanghai Lishan Biopharmaceuticals have signed an exclusive licensing agreement for BMC128, a microbiome-based therapeutic targeting renal and lung cancer. The treatment, developed by Biomica (Evogene's subsidiary), is currently completing its Phase 1 clinical study and showing promising early clinical results.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: From Rare Disease to Olympic Dreams: Athlete's Incredible Journey to Bobsled Glory
articles.excerpt: Jadin O'Brien battled a rare disease called PANDAS and overcame significant health challenges. The former Notre Dame heptathlete has now made it to the Olympics as a bobsledder, showcasing remarkable resilience and determination.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: Nature's Comeback: 800 Acres of Degraded Land Gets Second Chance at Life
articles.excerpt: About 800 acres of land degraded by illegal mining activities at Nyankumase in Ghana's Ashanti Region has been successfully reclaimed by the government. The restoration work, which started four months ago, is part of the Mahama government's efforts to restore lands damaged by illegal mining.
articles.author: Coral Reef

articles.headline: The Great Plastic Makeover: Recycled Packaging Market Soars to $58 Billion
articles.excerpt: The PCR plastic packaging market is projected to reach $58.27 billion by 2035, driven by global fiscal penalties and increased adoption of recycled packaging solutions. Brands in personal care, cleaning products, and retail are targeting higher PCR blends amid extended producer responsibility laws in multiple states.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: Wind Power Wins: Clean Energy Company's Profits Blow Past Expectations
articles.excerpt: Suzlon Energy reported a nearly 15% rise in Q3 profit to ₹445 crore, driven by increased revenue and a strong order book. The wind energy company's strong performance reflects growing demand for renewable energy solutions.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: Science Soothes: New Research Points to Better Burn Pain Relief
articles.excerpt: Researchers have discovered that Transforming growth factor beta 1 (TGF-β1) can relieve burn injury-induced pain by reducing inflammation in mouse studies. The multifunctional cytokine shows promise for addressing one of the most common and challenging symptoms burn patients face.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: DNA Detective Work Cracks the Code of Salamander Love Lives
articles.excerpt: Scientists used environmental DNA analysis to discover that Korean clawed salamanders have a biannual breeding season, solving a long-standing mystery about these subterranean creatures. The breakthrough research combines cutting-edge genetic techniques with population assessment to understand the species' life cycle.
articles.author: Bear Lee

articles.headline: Gaza Border Opens as Ceasefire Moves Forward
articles.excerpt: The Rafah crossing has opened as part of the second phase of the Gaza ceasefire plan. While more than 20,000 Gaza residents need medical treatment abroad, the early stage allows for 150 people to exit daily.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: This City Hasn't Had a Traffic Death in Nine Years (And Counting)
articles.excerpt: Hoboken, New Jersey, a city of 60,000 people, hasn't had a single fatal crash since January 17, 2017. While a typical U.S. city of this size would see around six to eight traffic fatalities every year, Hoboken has achieved nine consecutive years without any traffic deaths.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: High Schoolers Are Running Their Own Mental Health Hotline
articles.excerpt: High school students in Century City, California, are operating a mental health hotline during weekday evenings from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. PST. These teenagers settle into cubicles, put on headsets, and answer calls, texts, and emails from their peers who need support.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: India's Chess Revolution is Taking Over the World
articles.excerpt: Hundreds of children make their way to Marina Beach in Chennai on Sunday mornings despite soaring temperatures toward the 90s. India has become the most chess-obsessed country in the world, with a massive youth movement transforming the ancient game.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: China's Green Machine: Clean Energy Powers Economic Growth Like Never Before
articles.excerpt: China's clean energy industries drove more than 90% of the country's investment growth last year, making the sectors bigger than all but seven of the world's economies. For the second time in three years, the manufacture, installation and export of batteries, electric cars, solar, wind and related technologies accounted for more than a third of China's economic growth.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: Ireland's Wind Power Milestone: A Third of Electricity Now Comes from Breeze
articles.excerpt: Wind farms provided a third of Ireland's electricity in a record-breaking 2025. The increased wind energy production helped push down wholesale electricity prices from €136.99 per megawatt hour in December 2024 to €108.48 per megawatt hour in December 2025.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Webb Telescope Peers Deeper Into Cosmic History Than Ever Before
articles.excerpt: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has confirmed the existence of a bright galaxy that formed just 280 million years after the Big Bang. This discovery pushes the boundaries of the observable universe closer to the beginning than ever before, surpassing the previous record of a galaxy found 300 million years after the Big Bang.
articles.author: Nova Star

articles.headline: Big Cats, Little Meows: Jaguars Caught Making Adorable Sounds for Their Cubs
articles.excerpt: For the first time ever, researchers have recorded jaguars meowing while searching for their cubs. The world's third-largest feline, weighing over 300 pounds, makes sounds strikingly similar to domestic cats when calling for their young, as revealed by recent camera trap footage.
articles.author: Coral Bay

articles.headline: Art Meets Conservation: Rare Rembrandt Drawing Sells for $18M to Save Real Lions
articles.excerpt: A rare Rembrandt drawing of a lion sold at Sotheby's for a record $18 million, with proceeds going toward lion conservation. The drawing is one of only six drafts Rembrandt made of lions and the only one that had remained in private hands, belonging to Dr. Thomas S. Kaplan and his wife, prominent Rembrandt collectors who are also dedicated to wildlife conservation.
articles.author: Charity Case

articles.headline: Berlin's Beautiful Potato Problem: Bumper Harvest Feeds Everyone for Free
articles.excerpt: German potato farmers are experiencing what's being called a 'potato flood' - a record-breaking harvest that has created mountains of potatoes as far as the eye can see. The massive surplus has prompted widespread free potato giveaways across Berlin and nearby towns, ensuring the bumper crop feeds anyone and everyone in need.
articles.author: Sol Idarity

articles.headline: Ewe Won't Believe It: Therapy Sheep Help People Process Their Problems
articles.excerpt: A Yorkshire therapist has discovered that her intuitive flock of sheep provides an unexpected route to emotional healing. The sheep have proven remarkably effective at helping people unload their worries and find comfort through animal-assisted therapy sessions.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Owl Be Amazed: 1,400-Year-Old Zapotec Tomb Reveals Stunning Ancient Artistry
articles.excerpt: Archaeologists have uncovered what's being called the most significant archaeological discovery in a decade: a 1,400-year-old Zapotec tomb decorated with murals and carvings in exquisite preservation. The tomb's most striking feature is a frieze of an enormous owl head with a man's face trapped in its beak, belonging to one of Mexico's non-Mayan native cultures.
articles.author: Nova Star

articles.headline: Space Moss: The Ultimate Survivors That Make Jeff Goldblum Proud
articles.excerpt: The reproductive spores of Physcomitrella patens, a hardy pioneer moss species, managed to survive nine months in the vacuum of space while attached to the outside of the International Space Station. This remarkable discovery demonstrates the incredible resilience of life in the most extreme conditions imaginable.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Ice Storm Inspires Teen Architects to Build Community Spirit
articles.excerpt: After ice storms hit the mid-Atlantic region, teens Adeline Sutich and Maeve Ritchotte carved dozens of ice blocks to construct an igloo in front of a house destroyed by fire months earlier. Their creative project brought the entire neighborhood together during a challenging time.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: From Coal to Cool: How One French Town Reinvented Itself
articles.excerpt: The former mining town of Loos-en-Gohelle has transformed from one of Europe's largest coal mining regions into a sustainable community. The town's great slag heaps, once symbols of industrial pollution, now stand as monuments to successful environmental and economic renewal.
articles.author: Ray Solar

articles.headline: Working Parents Win With This Brilliant Childcare Solution
articles.excerpt: When Saja Khuder's childcare plans fell through and Chase Mateusiak's son was left exhausted by expensive daycare, they discovered an innovative solution. A new model combines affordable on-site childcare with coworking spaces, allowing parents to stay close while working.
articles.author: Sol Idarity

articles.headline: Deep Earth's Secret Architects Finally Revealed
articles.excerpt: Two massive hot rock structures deep inside Earth have been quietly shaping the planet's magnetic field for millions of years. Using ancient magnetic records and advanced simulations, scientists discovered these formations influence liquid iron movement in Earth's core, with some parts of the magnetic field remaining stable over vast time periods.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: Air Ambulance Heroes Are Beating the Survival Odds
articles.excerpt: Advanced care provided by air ambulance teams has led to higher survival rates in major trauma patients, with more people surviving than predicted by standard models. Younger patients and those more responsive at first assessment benefited most, while outcomes for traumatic cardiac arrest improved steadily over the study period.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: Saudi-Turkish Solar Partnership Sparks $2 Billion Green Investment
articles.excerpt: Saudi Arabia will invest approximately $2 billion to build solar power plants in Turkey as the first stage of a broader renewable-energy partnership between the two countries. The announcement has already boosted Turkish energy stocks as investors respond positively to the clean energy initiative.
articles.author: Sunny Bright

articles.headline: UK Links Green Energy Cash to Fair Work Standards
articles.excerpt: The UK government announced that offshore wind firms must sign up to a 'Fair Work Charter' to participate in government renewables auctions. This policy ties clean energy funding directly to stronger workers' rights in the renewable energy sector.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Toxic Factory Gets the Boot: When Good Journalism Forces Real Change
articles.excerpt: A factory processing US hazardous waste in Mexico has promised to relocate its most polluting operations following a Guardian investigation. The plant in the Monterrey metropolitan area recycles toxic steel dust sent by the US steel industry, and the investigation revealed evidence of heavy-metals pollution in surrounding neighborhoods.
articles.author: River Stone

articles.headline: Spraying Away Bird Flu: New Nasal Vaccine Packs a Powerful Punch
articles.excerpt: A new nasal spray vaccine showed strong protection against H5N1 in animal tests, outperforming traditional flu shots. Because it targets the nose and lungs, it may prevent infection at the earliest stage as researchers race to stop bird flu before it adapts to spread widely between people.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: Ancient Rock Stars: Australia's Underground Treasure Tells Earth's Story
articles.excerpt: Rare rocks buried deep in central Australia have revealed how a valuable niobium deposit formed during the breakup of an ancient supercontinent more than 800 million years ago. These unusual rocks contain niobium, a key ingredient in high-strength steel, electric vehicles, and emerging energy technologies.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: Ireland's Wind Power Hits Its Stride: One-Third of the Grid Goes Green
articles.excerpt: New figures published today show that Irish wind farms provided a third of the island of Ireland's electricity in 2025. This milestone represents a significant achievement in the country's renewable energy transition.
articles.author: Ray Solar

articles.headline: Plot Twist: Baby Dinosaurs Were the Real MVPs of Jurassic Ecosystems
articles.excerpt: Despite growing into the largest animals ever to walk on land, sauropods began life small, exposed, and alone. Fossil evidence suggests their babies were frequently eaten by multiple predators, making them a key part of the Jurassic food chain and explaining why early predators thrived without needing extreme hunting adaptations.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Tiny Minds, Big Ideas: Two-Month-Olds Are Already Little Philosophers
articles.excerpt: At just two months old, babies are already organizing the world in their minds. Brain scans revealed distinct patterns as infants looked at pictures of animals, toys, and everyday objects, showing early category recognition. Scientists used AI to help decode these patterns, offering a rare glimpse into infant thinking.
articles.author: Crystal Clear

articles.headline: Sneaky Brain Bug Finally Shows Its True Colors
articles.excerpt: A common parasite long thought to lie dormant is actually much more active and complex. Researchers found that Toxoplasma gondii cysts contain multiple parasite subtypes, not just one sleeping form. The discovery could reshape efforts to develop drugs that finally eliminate the parasite for good.
articles.author: Flora Fauna

articles.headline: Plastic-Eating Bacteria Just Got a New Champion
articles.excerpt: Scientists have discovered that Paenibacillus naphthalenovorans PETKKU2, isolated from landfill soil in Thailand, can break down polyethylene terephthalate microplastics. This study establishes PETKKU2 as the first reported member of this species capable of degrading PET microplastics.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: Tech Giants Team Up to Build Industrial AI Powerhouse
articles.excerpt: Dassault Systèmes and Nvidia announced a long-term strategic partnership to create a shared industrial artificial intelligence platform. The collaboration combines science-based virtual twins with large-scale AI infrastructure to support various applications.
articles.author: Nova Star

articles.headline: Virtual Reality Gets Real Results for Future Therapists
articles.excerpt: Researchers designed and evaluated an augmented reality-based virtual patient educational model to enhance clinical decision-making in occupational therapy students. The study aimed to improve student performance through technology-enhanced education, which is becoming an essential element of modern universities.
articles.author: Faith Healer

articles.headline: Squid Power: New Brain Treatment Gets FDA Thumbs Up
articles.excerpt: Balt's Squid™ liquid embolic agent just received FDA Premarket Approval for treating chronic subdural hematomas. The device works by embolizing the middle meningeal artery, offering patients a new treatment option for this serious brain condition.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: Powder to the People: 21,000 Sign Petition to Ski Fossil-Free
articles.excerpt: Norwegian skier Nikolai Schirmer delivered a petition signed by more than 21,000 people to the International Olympic Committee. The petition calls for ending fossil fuel company sponsorships of winter sports, aiming to clean up the industry's environmental image.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Green Power Surge: Tata's Renewable Business Jumps 156%
articles.excerpt: Despite flat overall profits at ₹1,194 crore, Tata Power's renewable energy business emerged as a standout performer. The green energy division saw profits surge 156% to ₹547 crore in the quarter, showing strong momentum in clean energy growth.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Wind Power Gets New Wings: Major Onshore Energy Acquisition
articles.excerpt: Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners has acquired Ørsted's European onshore renewable energy business. The acquisition strengthens CI V's European portfolio and reinforces the fund's position as a leading player in energy infrastructure and onshore renewables.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: Going Underground: Engineers Make Mountains Vanish for Progress
articles.excerpt: Engineers are building vital infrastructure deep underground, bypassing mountains with advanced physics and machinery to create efficient routes for travel and energy storage. Projects like the Gotthard Base Tunnel are transforming how we navigate challenging terrain using modern underground construction techniques.
articles.author: Flora Fauna

articles.headline: Gene-ius Move: Baby's Life Saved with World-First Personalized CRISPR Therapy
articles.excerpt: A Pennsylvania baby born with a rare metabolic disorder that prevents converting ammonia to urea has been successfully treated with personalized CRISPR gene therapy. The child, known as KJ, was at serious risk of brain or liver damage and had to be kept on medications and an extremely restrictive diet to avoid protein metabolism. The groundbreaking treatment has the child now thriving.
articles.author: Faith Healer

articles.headline: Turning Trash Into Treasure: Scientists Vaporize E-Waste for 13x Cheaper Metal Recovery
articles.excerpt: Scientists have discovered a way to extract precious metals from electronic waste by heating electronics to 3,000°C via electrical current. The method recovers decent grades of precious metals without creating hazardous waste. According to their analysis, relying on e-waste for precious metals supply could be 13 times cheaper than mining them from the ground.
articles.author: Adam Atom

articles.headline: Needle Relief: Rescued Elephants Find Healing Through Acupuncture in India
articles.excerpt: India's largest wildlife rescue organization has started using acupuncture to help elephants recover from chronic pain, nerve damage, and mobility issues after years of captivity or hard labor. Their veterinary team sought training in alternative medicine to use alongside conventional veterinary medicine. The treatment boosted recovery rates for the rescued elephants.
articles.author: Finn Waters

articles.headline: Memory Lane Restoration: Natural Aging Molecule Shows Promise for Alzheimer's
articles.excerpt: Researchers have found that a natural aging-related molecule can repair key memory processes affected by Alzheimer's disease. The compound improves communication between brain cells and restores early memory abilities that typically fade first. Because it already exists in the body and declines with age, boosting it may offer a safer way to protect the brain.
articles.author: Vi Tality

articles.headline: Living Drug Victory: Gene Therapy Conquers 'Untreatable' Blood Cancers
articles.excerpt: Gene therapy that turns white blood cells into a disease-busting 'living drug' has reversed previously untreatable blood cancers. The revolutionary treatment transforms patients' own immune cells into powerful cancer fighters.
articles.author: Hope Springs

articles.headline: Teen Hero Makes 4-Hour Ocean Rescue After Family Swept to Sea
articles.excerpt: A 13-year-old boy swam for 4 hours through rough seas to rescue his family after strong winds blew their inflatable paddleboards out to sea near Australia's southwest coast. The family of 4 was enjoying a holiday near Quindalup when they were separated by the conditions. The boy has been hailed as a hero for his superhuman effort.
articles.author: Hope Rising

articles.headline: Ancient Handprints Rewrite Human History at 67,800 Years Old
articles.excerpt: Stylized handprints dating back at least 67,800 years have been discovered in a limestone cave in Indonesia, breaking the country's own record for the world's oldest-known rock art. The discovery provides direct evidence that humans have been crossing the sea intentionally for nearly 70,000 years, as people traveled from the Asian continent across waters.
articles.author: Ella Ment

articles.headline: From Prairie to Ocean: Nebraska Woman Rows Into Record Books
articles.excerpt: Taryn Smith, 25, from landlocked Nebraska became the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race. Smith's ocean dreams took hold while living in Omaha, inspired by an article about an all-female rowing team that set a world record in the Great Pacific Race in 2022. She taught herself to row and completed the epic solo Atlantic crossing.
articles.author: Charity Case

articles.headline: Grandparent Brain Boost: Caring for Grandkids Fights Cognitive Decline
articles.excerpt: A new study shows that caring for grandchildren may serve as a buffer against cognitive decline and dementia in older adults. Research indicates that being an involved grandparent is good for the brain. Many grandparents provide regular care for their grandchildren, supporting families and society more broadly.
articles.author: Liv Long

articles.headline: Scientists Turn CO2 Into Fuel Using Dirt-Cheap Metal
articles.excerpt: Researchers have discovered that manganese, an abundant and inexpensive metal, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into formate, a potential hydrogen source for fuel cells. The clever redesign makes the catalyst last far longer than similar low-cost materials and even beats many expensive precious-metal options.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: The Gut-Brain Fix: New Protein Could Tackle Depression From the Inside Out
articles.excerpt: Scientists have found that chronic stress damages the gut's protective lining by lowering levels of a protein called Reelin, which plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. Remarkably, a single injection restored Reelin levels and produced antidepressant-like effects in preclinical models.
articles.author: Joy Fuller

articles.headline: NASA's New Space Explorer Starts Mapping Our Cosmic Bubble
articles.excerpt: NASA's IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe) began its two-year primary science mission on February 1. The mission will explore and map the boundaries of our heliosphere - the protective bubble created by the solar wind that surrounds our solar system.
articles.author: Al Gorithm

articles.headline: Solar Power Takes Night Shift Thanks to Battery Boom Down Under
articles.excerpt: Australia's love affair with home-grown renewable energy is driving booming battery sales and reshaping the electricity grid. Rooftop solar is now overtaking coal as more homeowners invest in battery storage to power their homes after dark.
articles.author: Gusty Winds

articles.headline: China's Solar Revolution: Clean Energy Set to Eclipse Coal
articles.excerpt: China's solar generating capacity is expected to surpass coal for the first time this year, according to the country's top electricity industry group. This marks a major milestone in the country's long-standing effort to build a cleaner power system.
articles.author: Marina Waters

articles.headline: Photographer's Mission: Saving India's Architectural Treasures One Click at a Time
articles.excerpt: A nationwide photography project is working to preserve India's rich architectural heritage through detailed documentation. The initiative focuses on capturing intricate details of historic buildings like Patwon Ki Haveli in Jaisalmer, with its carved balconies and latticed windows that echo with history.
articles.author: Will Prosper

articles.headline: Lost in Translation? Not When There's a Baby Coming
articles.excerpt: When a man who didn't speak English rushed into a New Jersey police station for help, two officers used Google Translate to understand the emergency. They then helped deliver a baby in the backseat of a car, overcoming the language barrier through quick thinking and technology.
articles.author: Will Prosper

articles.headline: World Goes 8+ Years Without Nuclear Weapons Testing—A Record Since Atomic Age
articles.excerpt: January 14th marked 8 years, 4 months, and 29 days since the last nuclear weapon was detonated on Earth. This represents the longest period without nuclear testing since the atomic age began in 1945.
articles.author: Pat Ontheback

articles.headline: These Kids Row Their Own Boats to School—And It's Actually Amazing
